channel.title: Pseudoscience on Alien Truth Social
channel.description: Recent content in Pseudoscience on Alien Truth Social

item.title: Ufology
item.description:
Ufology ðŸ”—

Ufology is the investigation of unidentified flying objects (UFOs) by individuals who believe they may have extraordinary origins, often extraterrestrial. While governments, private groups, and fringe science have investigated UFOs, ufology is generally considered pseudoscience by skeptics and science educators.

Etymology ðŸ”—

The term “ufology” is a neologism derived from “UFO” and the suffix “-logy.” Edward J. Ruppelt is credited with coining the term UFO. Early uses of “ufology” appeared in a 1957 Fantastic Universe article and a 1958 presentation for The Planetary Center.

Historical background ðŸ”—

Ufology’s roots trace back to various historical phenomena, including the mystery airships of the late 1890s, foo fighters reported during World War II, ghost fliers of the 1930s, ghost rockets of 1946 in Scandinavia, and the Kenneth Arnold sighting in 1947. The Arnold sighting popularized the concept of flying saucers. Increased UFO publicity after World War II coincided with Cold War tensions and concerns about Soviet aircraft. Official government involvement in ufology in the United States ended after the Condon Committee report and the termination of Project Blue Book. France maintains the GEIPAN program for UFO studies. In September 2023, NASA appointed Mark McInerney as the first Director of U.A.P. to study such occurrences scientifically.

As a field ðŸ”—

Ufology is not recognized as a scientific field by academia and is generally considered pseudoscience.

Status as a pseudoscience ðŸ”—

Ufology is often listed as a pseudoscience due to its lack of adherence to the scientific method, supporting evidence, plausibility, and falsifiability. Social factors contribute to this status, including mistrust between ufology, the sciences, and government bodies. Poor science communication regarding the extraterrestrial intelligence (ETI) hypothesis hinders public understanding and discourages academic inquiry.

Current interest ðŸ”—

Astronomer Avi Loeb launched The Galileo Project in 2021 to collect scientific evidence of extraterrestrial technology. The University of WÃ¼rzburg is developing sensors for detecting and analyzing aerial objects. A 2021 Gallup poll indicated increased belief among Americans that some UFOs are extraterrestrial spacecraft. In 2022, NASA announced a study to investigate UAP. In 2023, the RAND Corporation published a study reviewing public reports of UAP sightings in the United States from 1998 to 2022.

Methodological issues ðŸ”—

Scientific UFO research faces challenges due to the unpredictable nature of UFO phenomena, their lack of reproducibility, and tangible physicality. Most UFO sightings have mundane explanations, limiting the interpretive power of extraordinary events. Carl Sagan noted that reliable cases are uninteresting, and interesting cases are unreliable. J. Allen Hynek and Jacques VallÃ©e developed descriptive systems for characterizing UFO sightings.

Phenomena linked to ufology ðŸ”—

Ufologists are interested in phenomena related to UFO sightings, including crop circles, cattle mutilations, anomalous materials, alien abductions, and implants. Some ufologists promote UFO conspiracy theories, such as the Roswell Incident and the Majestic 12 documents. Robert Sheaffer has accused ufology of a “credulity explosion,” and James E. McDonald identified “cultism” as negatively impacting ufology.

In Posadism ðŸ”—

During the Cold War, ufology was combined with the ideas of the Trotskyist Posadism movement in South America. Juan Posadas, the main theorist, believed humanity should appeal to extraterrestrials to collaborate in suppressing poverty and creating a socialist system on Earth.

Governmental and private ufology studies ðŸ”—

Since the 1940s, governmental agencies and private groups have sponsored UFO investigations, studies, and conferences. These include Project Sign, Project Magnet, Project Blue Book, the Robertson Panel, and the Condon Committee in the United States; the Flying Saucer Working Party and Project Condign in Britain; GEIPAN in France; and Project Hessdalen in Norway. Private studies include those by the RAND Corporation, Harvey Rutledge, and the National Press Club’s Disclosure Project. The United Nations sponsored meetings and hearings on UFO sightings from 1977 to 1979. In August 2020, the United States Department of Defense established the Unidentified Aerial Phenomena Task Force.

UFO organizations and events ðŸ”—

Numerous private organizations worldwide are dedicated to the study and discussion of ufology. Skeptic organizations emphasize the pseudoscientific nature of ufology. During World UFO Day (July 2), ufologists raise public awareness of ufology.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ufologist

item.title: Ufology
item.description:
Ufology ðŸ”—

Ufology is the investigation of unidentified flying objects (UFOs) by individuals who believe they may have extraordinary origins, often extraterrestrial. While governments, private groups, and fringe science may investigate UFOs, ufology is generally considered pseudoscience by skeptics and science educators.

Etymology ðŸ”—

The term “ufology” is a neologism derived from “UFO” and the suffix “-logy.” Edward J. Ruppelt is credited with coining the term UFO. Early uses of “ufology” appeared in a 1957 Fantastic Universe article and a 1958 presentation for The Planetary Center.

Historical background ðŸ”—

Ufology’s roots can be traced to several historical phenomena: the “mystery airships” of the late 1890s, “foo fighters” reported during World War II, “ghost fliers” in the 1930s, “ghost rockets” in Scandinavia in 1946, and the Kenneth Arnold “flying saucer” sighting in 1947. The Arnold sighting significantly popularized the concept of flying saucers.

Increased UFO publicity after World War II coincided with the Cold War and concerns about Soviet aircraft. Official government activities related to ufology in the United States ended in the late 1960s after the Condon Committee report and the termination of Project Blue Book. Similar government-sponsored activities in other countries, such as the United Kingdom, Canada, Denmark, Italy, and Sweden, also ended. France is an exception, maintaining the GEIPAN program.

In September 2023, NASA appointed Mark McInerney as the Director of U.A.P. to study these occurrences scientifically and transparently.

As a field ðŸ”—

Ufology is not recognized as a scientific field of study by academia and is generally considered a pseudoscience.

Status as a pseudoscience ðŸ”—

Ufology is often listed as a pseudoscience because it lacks adherence to the scientific method, supporting evidence, plausibility, and falsifiability. Social factors contribute to this status, with some studies suggesting that mistrust between ufology, the sciences, and government bodies contributes to the perception of ufology as a pseudoscience. Poor science communication regarding the extraterrestrial intelligence (ETI) hypothesis also hinders public understanding and academic inquiry.

Current interest ðŸ”—

In 2021, Avi Loeb launched The Galileo Project to collect scientific evidence of extraterrestrials or their technology near Earth.

The University of WÃ¼rzburg in Germany is developing sensors to detect and analyze aerial objects for UAP applications.

A 2021 Gallup poll indicated an increase in the belief among Americans that some UFOs are extraterrestrial spacecraft.

In 2022, NASA announced a study to establish a roadmap for investigating UAP.

In 2023, the RAND Corporation published a study reviewing UAP sightings in the United States from 1998 to 2022, finding correlations between sightings and proximity to military operations areas.

Methodological issues ðŸ”—

Scientific UFO research faces challenges due to the unpredictable nature of the phenomena, lack of reproducibility, and absence of tangible physicality. Most UFO sightings have mundane explanations, limiting the interpretive power of extraordinary events. Carl Sagan noted that reliable cases are uninteresting, and interesting cases are unreliable.

J. Allen Hynek and Jacques VallÃ©e developed descriptive systems for characterizing UFO sightings and organizing ufology investigations.

Phenomena linked to ufology ðŸ”—

Certain phenomena are of interest to some ufologists, including crop circles, cattle mutilations, anomalous materials, alien abductions, and implants.

Some ufologists promote UFO conspiracy theories, such as the Roswell Incident, Majestic 12 documents, and UFO disclosure advocates.

Robert Sheaffer has accused ufology of a “credulity explosion,” where increasingly outlandish stories gain traction. James E. McDonald identified “cultism” and “extreme subgroups” as negatively impacting ufology.

In Posadism ðŸ”—

During the Cold War, ufology was combined with the ideas of Posadism, a Trotskyist movement in South America. Juan Posadas, the main theorist, believed humanity should appeal to extraterrestrials to help establish a socialist system on Earth. This belief contributed to the decline of Posadism as a political force.

Governmental and private ufology studies ðŸ”—

Starting in the 1940s, governmental agencies and private groups sponsored investigations, studies, and conferences related to ufology. These include Project Sign, Project Magnet, Project Blue Book, the Robertson Panel, and the Condon Committee in the United States; the Flying Saucer Working Party and Project Condign in Britain; GEIPAN in France; and Project Hessdalen in Norway. Private studies include those by the RAND Corporation, Harvey Rutledge of the University of Missouri, and the National Press Club’s Disclosure Project. The United Nations sponsored meetings and hearings concerning UFO sightings from 1977 to 1979. In August 2020, the United States Department of Defense established the Unidentified Aerial Phenomena Task Force.

UFO organizations and events ðŸ”—

Numerous private organizations worldwide are dedicated to the study, discussion, and publicity of ufology. Skeptic organizations also exist, emphasizing the pseudoscientific nature of ufology.

During World UFO Day (July 2), ufologists raise public awareness of ufology, including group gatherings to search for and observe UFOs.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/UFOlogists

item.title: Ufology
item.description:
Ufology ðŸ”—

Ufology is the investigation of unidentified flying objects (UFOs) by individuals who believe they may have extraordinary origins, often extraterrestrial. While governments, private groups, and fringe science may investigate UFOs, ufology is generally considered pseudoscience by skeptics and science educators.

Etymology ðŸ”—

The term “ufology” is a neologism derived from “UFO” and the suffix “-logy.” Edward J. Ruppelt is credited with coining the term UFO. Early uses of “ufology” appeared in a 1957 Fantastic Universe article and a 1958 presentation for The Planetary Center.

Historical background ðŸ”—

Ufology’s roots can be traced to several historical phenomena: the “mystery airships” of the late 1890s, “foo fighters” reported during World War II, “ghost fliers” of the 1930s, “ghost rockets” in Scandinavia in 1946, and the Kenneth Arnold “flying saucer” sighting in 1947. The Arnold sighting significantly popularized the concept of flying saucers.

Increased UFO publicity after World War II coincided with the Cold War and concerns about Soviet aircraft. Official government activities related to ufology in the United States ended in the late 1960s after the Condon Committee report and the termination of Project Blue Book. Similar government-sponsored activities in other countries, such as the United Kingdom, Canada, Denmark, Italy, and Sweden, also ended. France is an exception, maintaining the GEIPAN program.

In September 2023, NASA appointed Mark McInerney as the Director of U.A.P. to study such occurrences scientifically and transparently.

As a field ðŸ”—

Status as a pseudoscience ðŸ”—

Ufology is not recognized as a scientific field by academia and is generally considered a pseudoscience by skeptics and science educators. Pseudoscience lacks adherence to the scientific method, supporting evidence, plausibility, or falsifiability.

Social factors contribute to ufology’s status as a pseudoscience. Some argue that mistrust between ufology, the sciences, and government bodies contributes to this status. Poor science communication regarding the extraterrestrial intelligence (ETI) hypothesis for UFOs hinders public understanding and discourages academic inquiry.

Current interest ðŸ”—

In 2021, Avi Loeb launched The Galileo Project to collect scientific evidence of extraterrestrials or their technology near Earth.

The University of WÃ¼rzburg in Germany is developing sensors to detect and analyze aerial objects, potentially applicable to UAP.

A 2021 Gallup poll indicated an increase in the belief among Americans that some UFOs are extraterrestrial spacecraft.

In 2022, NASA announced a study to establish a roadmap for investigating UAP.

In 2023, the RAND Corporation published a study reviewing public reports of UAP sightings in the United States from 1998 to 2022.

Methodological issues ðŸ”—

Scientific UFO research faces challenges due to the unpredictable nature of the phenomena, lack of reproducibility, and absence of tangible physicality. Most UFO sightings have mundane explanations, limiting the interpretive power of extraordinary events. Carl Sagan noted that reliable cases are uninteresting, and interesting cases are unreliable.

J. Allen Hynek and Jacques VallÃ©e developed descriptive systems for characterizing UFO sightings and organizing ufology investigations.

Phenomena linked to ufology ðŸ”—

Certain phenomena are of interest to some ufologists, including crop circles, cattle mutilations, anomalous materials, alien abductions, and implants.

Some ufologists promote UFO conspiracy theories, including the Roswell Incident, Majestic 12 documents, and UFO disclosure advocates.

Robert Sheaffer has accused ufology of a “credulity explosion,” where increasingly outlandish stories gain traction. James E. McDonald identified “cultism” and “extreme subgroups” as negatively impacting ufology.

In Posadism ðŸ”—

During the Cold War, ufology was synthesized with Posadism, a Trotskyist movement in South America. Juan Posadas, the main theorist, believed humanity should appeal to extraterrestrials to collaborate in suppressing poverty and creating a socialist system on Earth. This belief contributed to the decline of Posadism.

Governmental and private ufology studies ðŸ”—

Starting in the 1940s, governmental agencies and private groups sponsored investigations, studies, and conferences related to ufology. These studies include Project Sign, Project Magnet, Project Blue Book, the Robertson Panel, and the Condon Committee in the United States; the Flying Saucer Working Party and Project Condign in Britain; GEIPAN in France; and Project Hessdalen in Norway. Private studies include those by the RAND Corporation, Harvey Rutledge of the University of Missouri, and the National Press Club’s Disclosure Project. The United Nations sponsored meetings and hearings concerning UFO sightings from 1977 to 1979. In August 2020, the United States Department of Defense established the Unidentified Aerial Phenomena Task Force to detect, analyze, and catalog unidentified aerial phenomena.

UFO organizations and events ðŸ”—

Numerous private organizations worldwide are dedicated to the study, discussion, and publicity of ufology. Skeptic organizations emphasize the pseudoscientific nature of ufology.

During World UFO Day (July 2), ufologists raise public awareness of ufology, including group gatherings to search for and observe UFOs.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ufological

item.title: Planetary objects proposed in religion, astrology, ufology and pseudoscience
item.description:
Non-scientific hypothetical objects ðŸ”—

This article discusses planetary objects proposed in religion, astrology, ufology, and pseudoscience that lack scientific evidence. It distinguishes these from scientifically accepted hypothetical astronomical objects and fictional planets in science fiction.

Kolob ðŸ”—

Kolob is a star or planet described in the Book of Abraham, a sacred text in the Latter Day Saint movement. While the Book of Abraham refers to Kolob as a “star,” it also refers to planets as stars, leading Latter Day Saints to commonly view Kolob as a planet. It is described as the heavenly body closest to the throne of God and is said to have “signified” the first creation according to Joseph Smith.

Lilith ðŸ”—

Lilith is a fictitious, invisible moon of Earth proposed in 1918 by astrologer Walter Gorn Old (Sepharial). Sepharial claimed Lilith was the same second moon that scientist Georg Waltemath claimed to have discovered twenty years earlier, but which was never confirmed. Sepharial claimed to be the first to observe Waltemath’s moon crossing the Sun. The scientific community had already discredited Waltemath’s proposed moon. While fringe groups believe in Lilith’s existence, astrologers now generally use the name for the position of the Moon’s apogee.

In modern astrology ðŸ”—

In modern astrology, “Lilith” or “Black Moon Lilith” refers to a point on the horoscope representing the Moon’s apogee. This point is sometimes defined as the second focus of the ellipse described by the Moon’s orbit. It takes approximately 8 years and 10 months for this point to complete a circuit through the zodiac, tracking the apsidal precession.

Planets proposed by L. Ron Hubbard ðŸ”—

L. Ron Hubbard, the founder of Scientology, proposed a Galactic Confederacy as part of his cosmology. This confederacy consisted of 26 stars and 76 planets, including Earth, then known as “Teegeeack.” Helatrobus is another planet mentioned in Scientology doctrine.

Ummo ðŸ”—

Ummo is a hypothetical planet believed to be located in the Constellation Virgo. A series of claims describe aliens from Ummo communicating with people on Earth through detailed documents and letters. The Ummo affair gained attention in France and Spain during the 1960s. Ummoism refers to groups interested in studying the ideas presented in the Ummo letters. JosÃ© Luis JordÃ¡n PeÃ±a has claimed responsibility for writing the letters and instigating Ummoism, leading many to believe Ummo is a hoax. Jacques VallÃ©e compared the Ummo documents to Borges’ “TlÃ¶n, Uqbar, Orbis Tertius.” Mike Dash notes that Ummoism began on February 6, 1966, in Madrid, when JordÃ¡n PeÃ±a claimed to have seen a circular object with a symbol resembling the alchemical sign for Uranus. Fernando Sesma Manzano, a contactee, became involved after receiving documents purportedly from the Ummites. Jean-Pierre Petit claims to have detected signs of superior intelligence in the Ummite writings and that they have inspired his research in cosmology and magnetohydrodynamics. Antonio Ribera compiled 403 Ummo words in 1978, and Jean Pollion listed over a thousand words in 2002.

Two theories have been formulated by analysts of Ummite letters:

  • Jean Pollion considers each letter (sound or phoneme) in words transcribed in typewritten form to be signifying, calling these sounds “soncepts” and considering the language to be “ideophonemic.”
  • The second theory considers that differences in spelling are of little significance and are due to differences in the understanding of foreign sounds by the typist(s), or to difficulties in alphabetic transcription, considering that language is made up of word-objects and not of “soncepts.”

More than 1300 pages of letters have been registered, with references to 3850 pages in a 1988 letter.

Dash notes that the photographic evidence was suspect, and the letters, while sophisticated, could have originated on Earth. Jerome Clark notes that Jacques VallÃ©e argued that the scientific content of the Ummo letters was knowledgeable but unremarkable, comparing the scientific references to a well-researched science fiction novel.

The controversy over an “error” in the distance from Wolf 424 arose from the first letter, referenced D21 (May 1966), which states that the distance used by terrestrial astronomers is different from the real distance in decadimensional space.

Planets proposed by Zecharia Sitchin ðŸ”—

Zecharia Sitchin’s work has gained attention among ufologists, ancient astronaut theorists, and conspiracy theorists. He claimed to have found evidence in Sumerian texts that the human race was visited/created by extraterrestrials from a distant planet in the Solar System. He interpreted the Babylonian creation myth, the Enuma Elish, by replacing the names of gods with hypothetical planets. Academics consider his work pseudoscience and pseudohistory.

Sitchin’s theory proposes the planets Tiamat and Nibiru. Tiamat supposedly existed between Mars and Jupiter, and its orbit was disrupted by the arrival of Nibiru. The collision of Tiamat with one of Nibiru’s moons supposedly formed the asteroid belt and Earth.

Sitchin claimed the Babylonians associated Nibiru with the god Marduk. He hypothesized it as a planet in a highly elliptic orbit around the Sun, with a perihelion passage some 3,600 years ago and an orbital period of about 3,450 years. He also claimed it was the home of the Anunnaki, a technologically advanced alien race who visited Earth in search of gold and created humanity by genetically crossing themselves with primates.

Websites such as ZetaTalk have claimed that Nibiru or “Planet X” is a brown dwarf within our planetary system, soon to pass close to Earth. Sitchin disagreed that it is a star, with the timing and parameters of passage.

Sitchin also postulated that Pluto began life as Gaga, a satellite of Saturn, which was flung into orbit beyond Neptune due to Nibiru’s passing.

Serpo ðŸ”—

Project Serpo is an alleged top-secret exchange program between the United States government and an alien planet called Serpo in the Zeta Reticuli star system. Details of the alleged exchange program have appeared in UFO conspiracy stories, including an incident in 1983 involving Richard C. Doty and Linda Moulton Howe, and emails sent to a UFO discussion group run by Victor Martinez in 2005. Some versions state that Serpo is the nickname of the extrasolar planet, while others claim it is a mispronunciation of Serponia or Seinu.

The first mention of Project Serpo was in a UFO email list maintained by Victor Martinez. According to the story, an alien survived a crash near Roswell in the late 1940s and was repatriated, leading to a relationship between the American government and the people of its home world in the Zeta Reticuli system.

The story claims that twelve American military personnel visited the planet between 1965 and 1978 and that all have since died from radiation levels from the two suns. Another version claims that eight team members returned, one died en route, one died on the planet, and two decided to remain on Serpo.

Criticism of Project Serpo stems from the lack of veracity of Richard Doty, who has been involved in other UFO-related activities and is considered a discredited source. There is no physical evidence supporting the project’s existence. Tim Swartz of Mysteries Magazine expressed that the details of Project Serpo have varied considerably with different accounts. It has been alleged that the entire series of posts were designed to be viral marketing for a new book by Doty.

Bill Ryan, a proponent of publicizing the Project Serpo claims, stepped down from his role as webmaster for the Serpo material but maintains his belief that an extraterrestrial exchange program did occur, although the Serpo releases contained disinformation.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Planetary_objects_proposed_in_religion,_astrology,_ufology_and_pseudoscience

item.title: Ancient Aliens Episodes
item.description:
Ancient Aliens Episodes ðŸ”—

Ancient Aliens is an American television series that explores the ancient astronauts hypothesis and other pseudoscientific topics. It is narrated by Robert Clotworthy and produced by Prometheus Entertainment. The series has been criticized for promoting unproven hypotheses as fact.

Series Overview ðŸ”—

This section provides a table summarizing the number of episodes per season and the original release dates for each season, starting with the pilot episode in 2009 and continuing through season 21, scheduled for 2025.

Broadcast Episodes ðŸ”—

This section lists all episodes broadcast under the Ancient Aliens title card. Episode availability varies by broadcast market and language.

Season 1 (2009â€“10) ðŸ”—

The 2009 Ancient Aliens documentary was retitled “Chariots, Gods & Beyond” and packaged as the series pilot. All episodes, except the pilot, carry the Ancient Aliens: The Series title card. The section lists the pilot episode and the five episodes of the first season, including their titles and original release dates.

Season 2 (2010) ðŸ”—

This section lists the ten episodes of the second season, including their titles and original release dates.

Season 3 (2011) ðŸ”—

This section lists the sixteen episodes of the third season, including their titles and original release dates.

Season 4 (2012) ðŸ”—

This section lists the ten episodes of the fourth season, including their titles and original release dates.

Season 5 (2012â€“13) ðŸ”—

This section lists the twelve episodes of the fifth season, including their titles and original release dates.

Season 6 (2013) ðŸ”—

This section lists the eleven episodes of the sixth season, including their titles and original release dates.

Season 7 (2014) ðŸ”—

This section lists the eight episodes of the seventh season, including their titles and original release dates.

Season 8 (2014) ðŸ”—

This section lists the nine episodes of the eighth season, including their titles and original release dates.

Season 9 (2014â€“15) ðŸ”—

This section lists the twelve episodes of the ninth season, including their titles and original release dates.

Season 10 (2015) ðŸ”—

This section lists the ten episodes of the tenth season, including their titles and original release dates.

Season 11 (2016) ðŸ”—

This section lists the fifteen episodes of the eleventh season, including their titles and original release dates.

Season 12 (2017) ðŸ”—

This section lists the sixteen episodes of the twelfth season, including their titles and original release dates.

Season 13 (2018â€“19) ðŸ”—

This section lists the fifteen episodes of the thirteenth season, including their titles and original release dates.

Season 14 (2019) ðŸ”—

This section lists the twenty-two episodes of the fourteenth season, including their titles and original release dates.

Season 15 (2020) ðŸ”—

This section lists the twelve episodes of the fifteenth season, including their titles and original release dates. It mentions the Nan Madol episode and the Skinwalker Ranch episode.

Season 16 (2020â€“21) ðŸ”—

This section lists the ten episodes of the sixteenth season, including their titles, original release dates, and U.S. viewer numbers in millions. It mentions the episode featuring William Shatner.

Season 17 (2021) ðŸ”—

This section lists the seven episodes of the seventeenth season, including their titles and original release dates. It mentions the Mount Shasta episode.

Season 18 (2022) ðŸ”—

This section lists the twenty episodes of the eighteenth season, including their titles and original release dates. Six episodes were broadcast as Ancient Aliens on Location.

Season 19 (2023) ðŸ”—

This section lists the twenty episodes of the nineteenth season, including their titles, original release dates, and U.S. viewer numbers in millions.

Season 20 (2024) ðŸ”—

This section lists the twenty episodes of the twentieth season, including their titles, original release dates, and U.S. viewer numbers in millions for the first eight episodes.

Season 21 (2025) ðŸ”—

This section lists the first eight episodes of the upcoming twenty-first season, including their titles and original release dates.

Special Episodes ðŸ”—

This section details special episodes that include new footage in addition to selections from previously broadcast episodes. Availability varies by broadcast market and language.

Special Edition (2014) ðŸ”—

Ancient Aliens: Special Edition features highlights from previously broadcast episodes, including extended interviews and new effects. The episodes were originally broadcast as part of Season 8.

The Ultimate Evidence (2015) ðŸ”—

Ancient Aliens: The Ultimate Evidence is a repackage of previously broadcast episodes presented by Giorgio Tsoukalos.

Special Presentation (2022â€“2024) ðŸ”—

Ancient Aliens: Special Presentation features highlights from previously broadcast episodes in a 90-minute format, with many segments presented in high-definition for the first time, along with new interview footage and special effects.

Season 1 (2022â€“23) ðŸ”—

This section lists the thirteen episodes of the first season of Ancient Aliens: Special Presentation, including their titles and original release dates.

Season 2 (2023â€“24) ðŸ”—

This section lists the twelve episodes of the second season of Ancient Aliens: Special Presentation, including their titles and original release dates.

Origins (2024â€“25) ðŸ”—

Ancient Aliens: Origins is a repackage of previously broadcast episodes in a 90-minute format, with new on-location segments and interviews.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Ancient_Aliens_episodes

item.title: Ancient astronauts
item.description:
Ancient Astronauts ðŸ”—

Ancient astronauts, also known as ancient aliens, is a pseudoscientific belief that intelligent extraterrestrial beings visited Earth in ancient times and influenced human civilization. Proponents suggest that these aliens affected the development of cultures, technologies, religions, and even human biology. A common idea is that deities in many religions were actually extraterrestrials, and their advanced technologies were seen as divine powers by early humans.

This idea is rejected by academics and archaeologists, who consider it pseudoarchaeology and unscientific. Claims are often based on distorted or fabricated evidence. Some critics argue that ancient astronaut theories have racist implications, diminishing the achievements of indigenous cultures.

Notable proponents in the late 20th century include Robert Charroux, Jacques Bergier, Jean Sendy, Erich von DÃ¤niken, Alexander Kazantsev, Zecharia Sitchin, Robert K. G. Temple, Giorgio A. Tsoukalos, David Hatcher Childress, Peter Kolosimo, and Mauro Biglino.

Overview ðŸ”—

Various terms are used to describe claims about ancient astronauts, including ancient aliens, ancient ufonauts, ancient space pilots, paleocontact, astronaut- or alien gods, and paleo- or biblical-SETI.

Believers often claim that humans are descendants or creations of extraterrestrial intelligence that landed on Earth in the past. They suggest that human knowledge, religion, and culture originated from these ancient alien visitors, who acted as a “mother culture.” Proponents also claim that extraterrestrials built or helped humans build structures like the Egyptian pyramids and the Moai stone heads of Easter Island. Evidence is said to come from gaps in historical and archaeological records, as well as artifacts that are considered anachronistic and beyond the technical capabilities of ancient people. These “out-of-place artifacts” include artwork and legends reinterpreted to support extraterrestrial contact.

The idea is featured in fringe media, such as the History Channel series Ancient Aliens. The show mixes fact with fiction to promote theories of an alternate past, often incorporating white supremacist, nativist, imperialist, settler-colonial, and Christian Identity beliefs. Proponents portray themselves as an oppressed minority of academics challenging mainstream archaeology, despite lacking credentials.

Like past archaeological endeavors, the focus is on monumental structures, suggesting that indigenous people could not have built them without alien help. However, some indigenous voices argue that ancient alien theory supports their stories of extraterrestrial origins.

A common theme is the portrayal of aliens as light-skinned or Aryan, as claimed by Erich von DÃ¤niken. Some proponents are associated with white supremacism.

Mainstream archaeologists have largely ignored these claims, while popular science explainers and skeptics have criticized them. Carl Sagan noted that cases of apparent interest have reasonable alternative explanations, misreporting, or are hoaxes and distortions.

History of Ancient Aliens Beliefs and Their Proponents ðŸ”—

Paleocontact narratives appeared in early science fiction of the late 19th and early 20th centuries, including Edison’s Conquest of Mars (1898) and the works of H.P. Lovecraft. Harold T. Wilkins proposed the idea in earnest in 1954. It gained popularity in the 1960s due to the Space Race and Erich von DÃ¤niken’s works. Critics emerged in the 1970s, discrediting Von DÃ¤niken’s claims. By the early 1980s, support dwindled.

Shklovskii and Sagan ðŸ”—

Carl Sagan co-authored Intelligent Life in the Universe (1966) with Soviet astrophysicist Iosif Shklovsky. In Broca’s Brain (1979), Sagan expressed disapproval of writers like von DÃ¤niken who treated speculations as valid evidence of extraterrestrial contact. Sagan noted that many legends, artifacts, and out-of-place artifacts cited in support of ancient astronaut hypotheses could be explained with conventional hypotheses. He reiterated that extraterrestrial visits were possible but unproven and improbable.

Erich von DÃ¤niken ðŸ”—

Erich von DÃ¤niken became a leading proponent in the late 1960s and early 1970s with his book Chariots of the Gods? (1968) and its sequels.

Von DÃ¤niken argued that certain artifacts required more advanced technology than was available to ancient cultures. He claimed that these artifacts were constructed by extraterrestrial visitors or humans who learned from them. Examples include Stonehenge, Pumapunku, the Moai of Easter Island, the Great Pyramid of Giza, and the ancient Baghdad electric batteries.

He wrote that ancient art and iconography depict air and space vehicles, intelligent non-human creatures, ancient astronauts, and advanced technology. He also stated that geographically separated cultures share artistic themes, implying a common origin. One example is his interpretation of the sarcophagus lid from the tomb of Pacal the Great in Palenque, which he saw as a seated astronaut, while Maya texts identify it as a portrait of the ruler with the World Tree.

Von DÃ¤niken interpreted the origins of many religions as reactions to encounters with an alien race, whose technology was seen as supernatural. He stated that religious traditions contain references to alien visitors, such as Ezekiel’s revelation, which he interpreted as a landing spacecraft.

His hypotheses became popularized in the U.S. through the NBC-TV documentary In Search of Ancient Astronauts and the film Chariots of the Gods.

Critics argue that von DÃ¤niken misrepresented data, made unfounded claims, and failed to validate his core claims. Christian creationists also criticized his work.

Regarding the Nazca Lines, von DÃ¤niken stated that they resembled an airfield when seen from the air. Kenneth L. Feder argues that readers seeing the Nazca Lines in a book about aliens would be more likely to associate them with extraterrestrial origins.

In 1970, von DÃ¤niken admitted that the Nazca markings could have been laid out using a system of coordinates.

Zecharia Sitchin ðŸ”—

Zecharia Sitchin’s The Earth Chronicles series revolves around his interpretation of ancient Sumerian and Middle Eastern texts, megalithic sites, and artifacts. He hypothesized that the gods of Mesopotamia were astronauts from the planet Nibiru, which the Sumerians believed to be a remote “12th planet” associated with the god Marduk. According to Sitchin, Nibiru orbits the Sun on a 3,600-year elongated orbit. Modern astronomy has found no evidence to support these ideas.

Sitchin argued that Sumerian texts tell the story of 50 Anunnaki from Nibiru who came to Earth approximately 400,000 years ago to mine raw materials, especially gold. They genetically engineered laborers, creating Homo sapiens sapiens: the “Adapa” or Adam of later mythology. Sitchin contended that the Anunnaki were active in human affairs until their culture was destroyed by global catastrophes caused by the end of the last ice age.

His work has not received mainstream scholarly support and has been criticized by professionals. Semitic languages scholar Michael S. Heiser says that many of Sitchin’s translations are inconsistent with Mesopotamian cuneiform dictionaries.

Alan F. Alford, author of Gods of the New Millennium, initially adhered to Sitchin’s hypotheses but later found fault, stating that the gods personified the falling sky and that the descent of the gods was a poetic rendition of the cataclysm myth.

Robert Temple ðŸ”—

Robert K. G. Temple’s 1976 book, The Sirius Mystery, argues that the Dogon people of northwestern Mali preserved an account of extraterrestrial visitation from around 5,000 years ago. He cites advanced astronomical knowledge, descriptions, and comparative belief systems with ancient civilizations. His work draws on the studies of cultural anthropologists Marcel Griaule and Germaine Dieterlen.

His conclusions have been criticized by scientists, who point out discrepancies and suggest that the Dogon may have received their astronomical information recently from European sources.

UFO Religions ðŸ”—

Various new religious movements, including some branches of Theosophy, Scientology, RaÃ«lism, Aetherius Society, and Heaven’s Gate, believe in ancient and present-day contact with extraterrestrial intelligence. Many see ancient scriptures and recent revelations as connected with the action of aliens. Psychologists have found that UFO religions have similarities suggesting that members associate enchantment with science fiction memes.

Claims of Proponents ðŸ”—

The scientific consensus is that the ancient astronaut hypothesis is not impossible, but unjustified and unnecessary. The “mysteries” cited as evidence can be explained without invoking ancient astronauts. Since ancient astronauts are unnecessary, Occam’s razor should be applied and the hypothesis rejected.

Ancient Religious Texts ðŸ”—

Proponents cite ancient mythologies, suggesting that creation myths of gods descending from the heavens to create or instruct humanity are representations of alien visitors. They draw an analogy to cargo cults, where isolated cultures believed Western ships and cargo were sent from the gods.

The ancient Sumerian myth of EnÃ»ma EliÅ¡ says humankind was created to serve gods called the “Annunaki.” Proponents believe that the Annunaki were aliens who came to Earth to mine gold and created the human race as slaves.

Ramayana ðŸ”—

In Hindu mythology, the gods and their avatars travel in flying vehicles called Vimana. The Ramayana mentions these flying objects, used by the Lankan king Ravana from Sri Lanka.

Examples from the Ramayana include descriptions of the Pushpak chariot, a

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ancient_astronauts

item.title: Ancient Aliens
item.description:
Ancient Aliens ðŸ”—

Ancient Aliens is an American television series that explores the pseudoscientific ancient astronauts hypothesis. It presents unorthodox theories about extraterrestrial visitations in ancient times, often without critical analysis. The show has been criticized for promoting pseudoscience and pseudohistory.

Genre: Pseudoscience, Pseudohistory, Ufology, Conspiracy theory Narrator: Robert Clotworthy Country of Origin: United States Original Language: English Number of Seasons: 21 Number of Episodes: 268

Production ðŸ”—

The series is produced by Prometheus Entertainment. Kevin Burns served as executive producer from 2009 to 2021. Giorgio A. Tsoukalos is a consulting producer and featured guest. UFO researcher C. Scott Littleton was a producing consultant until his death in 2010.

Ancient Aliens began as a two-hour documentary special on the History Channel in 2009. It became a flagship series on History from 2010 to 2012, then moved to H2 from 2012 to 2014. In 2015, it returned to History after H2 was relaunched as Vice on TV. A fifteenth season premiered in 2020, with subsequent seasons following.

Premise and cosmology ðŸ”—

The series is based on the ancient astronauts hypothesis popularized by Erich von DÃ¤niken in Chariots of the Gods? and Zecharia Sitchin in The 12th Planet. This hypothesis suggests that extraterrestrial beings visited Earth in the distant past and influenced the development of human civilization, technology, and architecture. Ancient achievements like the Egyptian pyramids, Pumapunku, Teotihuacan, and Stonehenge are attributed to extraterrestrial influence.

The series suggests that remnants of these visitations can be found in religious texts, ancient myths, and legendary histories, including those of Hinduism, Ancient Egyptian religion, Gnostic Christianity, and Mormonism. It also proposes that modern humans may be the result of genetic modification by or biological descendants of ancient astronauts.

The series often avoids precise dates, using terms like “the remote past” or “ancient times.” A common demarcation point is “before or after ‘The Ice Age’,” or approximately 12,000 years ago. Some guests, such as Graham Hancock and Robert Schoch, suggest that a sophisticated human civilization predated our own and was destroyed at the end of the Ice Age.

The series features guests who support these claims and promote the idea of a shared cosmogony and cosmology, with significance placed on Sirius, Orion, Pleiades, the Moon, and Mars.

Presentation style ðŸ”—

The series presents claims made by guests in an uncritical and fast-paced manner. The narration often frames these claims as rhetorical questions, answered with “ancient alien theorists say yes.” After a claim is introduced, the narration often cuts away with, “Perhaps more evidence can be found…” before introducing another location or event with a hypothetical connection. This presentation style has been described as a Gish gallop.

Geologist Robert Schoch has stated that his interviews for the series have been edited in a way that is out of context or disconnected from the questions asked.

Writer David Childress frequently concludes his comments with the exclamation, “â€”probably extraterrestrials!” Childress and Giorgio Tsoukalos assert that prehistoric peoples lacked the vocabulary to describe advanced technology, and thus referred to extraterrestrial visitors as gods.

Terms such as “ancient astronauts,” “ancient aliens,” “alien visitors,” “extra-terrestrial beings,” “ancient gods,” and “otherworldly beings” are used interchangeably. Guests often conflate the meaning of “theory” and “hypothesis,” or obscure the difference between mythology and verifiable archaeology, anthropology, or documented history.

Frequent guests ðŸ”—

The series features a range of guests, including credentialed scientists and professionals, as well as proponents of the ancient astronaut hypothesis.

Some frequent guests include:

  • Sara Seager
  • Michael Denning
  • Jonathan Young
  • Robert Schoch
  • Erich von DÃ¤niken
  • George Noory
  • Barry Downing
  • Robert Bauval
  • Graham Hancock
  • Nick Pope
  • Travis S. Taylor

Evidence ðŸ”—

Many episodes offer little empirical evidence to support the claims presented. Episodes often focus on out-of-place artifacts, such as the London Hammer, Antikythera mechanism, or the Aiud object. Guests discuss evidence in general or abstract terms. Some guests allege that professionals and government officials have suppressed evidence of ancient mysteries.

From Season 12 onward, some episodes have included on-camera tests conducted by scientists and medical professionals on evidence that potentially supports the ancient astronauts hypothesis. However, none of the results have proven conclusive.

Other claims ðŸ”—

The series explores other claims linked to the ancient astronauts hypothesis, including UFOs, alien abductions, the Roswell incident, Rendlesham Forest incident, panspermia, and human space exploration. Guests have presented pseudohistorical and pseudoscientific hypotheses related to Atlantis, ley lines, cataclysmic pole shifts, creationism, and legendary history.

Other concepts explored include faith healing, remote viewing, psychic phenomena, and catastrophism. Guests have claimed that prominent historical figures were influenced by or were possibly “extra-terrestrial” or “otherworldly beings.” Guests have also discussed unrelated pseudoscientific claims, such as dinosaurs coexisting with humans, crystal healing, crystal skulls, Freemasonry, Rosicrucianism, and the New World Order.

Linda Moulton Howe appears in several episodes which explore alien abduction, animal mutilation, and conspiracies involving alleged military installations on Antarctica. The 2013 Citizen Hearing on Disclosure features prominently in numerous episodes.

Prior to December 2012, several episodes explored aspects of the 2012 Mayan doomsday prophecy. Episodes focusing on Mesoamerica broadcast after 2012 make no mention of the 2012 phenomenon.

Episodes ðŸ”—

The series consists of 21 seasons, including a pilot episode.

Reception ðŸ”—

The program has attracted millions of viewers.

Critical response ðŸ”—

The series has been criticized by historians, cosmologists, archaeologists, and other scientists for presenting pseudoscience, pseudohistory, and pseudoarchaeology as fact. Episodes are often characterized as “far-fetched” and “hugely speculative.” Many of the claims made by guests are not commonly accepted by the scientific community.

Brad Lockwood of Forbes characterized Ancient Aliens as an example of History’s channel drift toward “programs devoted to monsters, aliens, and conspiracies.” Alex Knapp, also of Forbes, cited archaeologist Keith Fitzpatrick-Matthews’ rebuke of History for treating “nonsense as though it were fact.”

In 2011, South Park parodied the series in the episode “A History Channel Thanksgiving.”

Science writer Riley Black was critical of the series, accusing it of employing a Gish gallop technique to overwhelm the viewer with many “fictions and distortions.”

Kenneth Feder, Professor of Archaeology at Central Connecticut State University, stated that he was approached by producers with requests to appear in several episodes, but was not contacted again after stating his belief that the ancient astronaut hypothesis is “execrable bullshit.”

In 2016, Vice on TV producer Jordan Kinley said of Ancient Aliens claims: “You feel kind of lost when someone questions the historical narrative you’ve been taught. I don’t believe much of what’s talked about … but I think it’s a good time for people to realize that some of our history is manufactured. Some of it is manufactured to be accurate, and some of it is manufactured to excuse horrible things that have happened.”

In the 2019 issue of Public Archaeology, Franco D. Rossi of Johns Hopkins University characterized Ancient Aliens and its fans as a “science fiction fandom” which also trafficked in “misinformation” and “conspiracies.”

In March 2020, podcaster Brian Dunning challenged and debunked many of the claims featured on Ancient Aliens.

Critical response by guests ðŸ”—

Many guests featured in episodes of the series have publicly expressed skepticism of the series’ premise or of the ancient astronaut hypothesis.

At a 2014 hearing of the House Committee on Science, Seth Shostak said that there is not any evidence which has convinced him “that we were visited in [historical] times.”

In a 2018 episode of The Joe Rogan Experience, Robert Schoch said promoters of the ancient astronaut hypothesis “want everything to be ‘ancient aliens’”, which in his view was “sort of a cop-out”.

William Shatner, who appeared in the Season 16 episode “William Shatner Meets Ancient Aliens”, told Inverse: “I had some spirited discussions with these experts who believe aliens were here, and like most people, I was dubious about the whole thing.”

Related media ðŸ”—

Many guests featured on Ancient Aliens appear in other History channel series and specials.

Ancient Aliens meme ðŸ”—

Tsoukalos’s appearances in Ancient Aliens inspired a meme highlighting his unusual hairstyle overlaid with the caption: “I’m not saying it was aliens … but …”

Alien Con ðŸ”—

From 2016 to 2018, A&E Networks co-produced several installments of Alien Con, a fan convention inspired by the series.

ðŸ”—

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ancient_Aliens

item.title: In Search of Aliens
item.description:
In Search of Aliens ðŸ”—

In Search of Aliens is a 2014 American television series that aired on the H2 channel. The show is presented by Giorgio A. Tsoukalos, a prominent figure from Ancient Aliens, and explores topics related to pseudoscience, ufology, and conspiracy theories, particularly the ancient astronaut theory.

Episodes ðŸ”—

This section lists the titles of all ten episodes of the single season of In Search of Aliens. The episodes cover a range of topics, including:

  • The Hunt for Atlantis
  • Nazi Time Travelers
  • The Mystery of Loch Ness
  • The Roswell Rock
  • Searching for Bigfoot
  • The Mystery of the Cyclops
  • The Mystery of Puma Punku
  • The Founding of America
  • The Mystery of Nazca
  • The Alien Code

Criticism ðŸ”—

The show has faced criticism from reviewers and organizations. Jason Colavito criticized the show for lacking a clear thesis and for Tsoukalos’ apparent skepticism towards his interviewees’ claims. The Southern Poverty Law Center (SPLC), through Alexander Zaitchik’s Hatewatch blog, has criticized shows like In Search of Aliens for promoting “racist pseudo-scholarship” and raising the profile of figures like Jan Udo Holey, whose antisemitic works have been banned in Europe.

See also ðŸ”—

This section provides a list of related topics and television programs, including:

  • List of topics characterized as pseudoscience
  • Pseudoarchaeology
  • Ancient Aliens
  • Unsealed Alien Files
  • In Search of… (TV series)

References ðŸ”—

This section lists the sources cited in the article, including links to History.com, Jason Colavito’s website, and the Southern Poverty Law Center’s Hatewatch blog.

External links ðŸ”—

This section provides a link to the show’s page on IMDb.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/In_Search_of_Aliens
